title: Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant for provision of medical supplies to respond to Ebola outbreak
description: On September 29, 2014, the Government of Ghana and People’s Republic of China signed a grant agreement worth RMB 5 million for the provision of medical supplies to respond to an Ebola outbreak. H. E. Sun Baohong, China Ambassador to Ghana signed the agreement on behalf of China and Hon. Cassiel Ato Forson, MP, Deputy Minister of Finance, signed the agreement on behalf of the Government of Ghana. These medical supplies included protective equipment, sprayers, non-contact infrared body thermometers, and body temperature detectors. These materials were successfully delivered to the Ghanaian authorities on October 31, 2014.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 5 million grant for provision of medical supplies to respond to Ebola outbreak

# Description
On September 29, 2014, the Government of Ghana and People’s Republic of China signed a grant agreement worth RMB 5 million for the provision of medical supplies to respond to an Ebola outbreak. H. E. Sun Baohong, China Ambassador to Ghana signed the agreement on behalf of China and Hon. Cassiel Ato Forson, MP, Deputy Minister of Finance, signed the agreement on behalf of the Government of Ghana. These medical supplies included protective equipment, sprayers, non-contact infrared body thermometers, and body temperature detectors. These materials were successfully delivered to the Ghanaian authorities on October 31, 2014.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare response to a public health emergency, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Provision of medical supplies for Ebola outbreak response, including protective equipment and diagnostic tools

title: Chinese Government provides $1.5 million grant for Residential Solar Street Lights Project
description: On August 8, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ghana signed a $1.5 million grant agreement for the Residential Solar Street Lights Project. This project involved the provision and installation 275 LED street lights for improved improved night lighting in Accra. Huawei Technologies was the contractor responsible for project implementation. As of August 1, 2014, 260 solar street lights had been put into use. The remaining 15 were expected to be put into use shortly thereafter. According to Ghana’s Deputy Minister of Energy, this project not only improved the visibility of roads at night, but also improved the safety of bus stops and night shift vehicles.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 加纳太阳能项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
Chinese Government provides $1.5 million grant for Residential Solar Street Lights Project

# Description
On August 8, 2014, the Chinese Government and the Government of Ghana signed a $1.5 million grant agreement for the Residential Solar Street Lights Project. This project involved the provision and installation 275 LED street lights for improved improved night lighting in Accra. Huawei Technologies was the contractor responsible for project implementation. As of August 1, 2014, 260 solar street lights had been put into use. The remaining 15 were expected to be put into use shortly thereafter. According to Ghana’s Deputy Minister of Energy, this project not only improved the visibility of roads at night, but also improved the safety of bus stops and night shift vehicles.
justification: Primary purpose is solar-powered street lighting, directly supporting renewable energy use
evidence: 275 LED solar street lights, renewable energy focus, improved energy efficiency

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for provision of 17 buses
description: In 2014, the Chinese Government agreed to donate seventeen 35-seat buses to the Government of Ghana worth RMB 10 million. Zhongtong Bus Holdings Company was the manufacturer of the buses. The buses were shipped in November 2014 and they arrived in Ghana on February 17, 2015. The handover ceremony took place on February 17, 2015. It was attended by China’s Ambassador to Ghana Sun Baohong and Ghana’s Minister of Communications Qifa Atifar.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 援助加纳大客车
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for provision of 17 buses

# Description
In 2014, the Chinese Government agreed to donate seventeen 35-seat buses to the Government of Ghana worth RMB 10 million. Zhongtong Bus Holdings Company was the manufacturer of the buses. The buses were shipped in November 2014 and they arrived in Ghana on February 17, 2015. The handover ceremony took place on February 17, 2015. It was attended by China’s Ambassador to Ghana Sun Baohong and Ghana’s Minister of Communications Qifa Atifar.
justification: Project involves provision of buses without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of 17 standard buses, no mention of energy efficiency or alternative fuel technology

title: Chinese Government dispatches 4th medical team to Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital in Ghana
description: The 4th Chinese medical team included 10 members from Guangdong Province who were stationed at Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital in Accra. They completed their term of service between December 13, 2014 and December 19, 2015. The team was sent by the Guangzhou Municipal Health System.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 4th medical team to Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital in Ghana

# Description
The 4th Chinese medical team included 10 members from Guangdong Province who were stationed at Korle-Bu Teaching Hospital in Accra. They completed their term of service between December 13, 2014 and December 19, 2015. The team was sent by the Guangzhou Municipal Health System.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team deployment to hospital, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese Government organizes counter-IED training for Ghanaian security officials
description: From May 12 to June 10, 2014, the Chinese government sponsored a Counter-IED training course for Ghanaian security staff. The training courses were held in China, and attended by 20 security staff members from airports across Ghana, including Kotoka International Airport. Before they left, they were visited by Gao Wenzhi, Chinese Ambassador to Ghana, and Charles Asare, manager of the airport.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government organizes counter-IED training for Ghanaian security officials

# Description
From May 12 to June 10, 2014, the Chinese government sponsored a Counter-IED training course for Ghanaian security staff. The training courses were held in China, and attended by 20 security staff members from airports across Ghana, including Kotoka International Airport. Before they left, they were visited by Gao Wenzhi, Chinese Ambassador to Ghana, and Charles Asare, manager of the airport.
justification: Project focuses on security training without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Counter-IED training for security staff, government-sponsored capacity building initiative

title: Chinese Embassy provides grant for establishment of Philip Akpo Memorial School in the Volta Region (linked to #60148)
description: On June 24, 2014, the Chinese Embassy in Ghana officially handed over a China-Ghana Friendship ICT Lab to Philip Akpo Memorial School in the Volta Region. The lab reportedly included 5 computers, tables and chairs, switches, routers, rack, a projector and projector screen and an 8 KVA UPS valued at GHS 80,000.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy provides grant for establishment of Philip Akpo Memorial School in the Volta Region (linked to #60148)

# Description
On June 24, 2014, the Chinese Embassy in Ghana officially handed over a China-Ghana Friendship ICT Lab to Philip Akpo Memorial School in the Volta Region. The lab reportedly included 5 computers, tables and chairs, switches, routers, rack, a projector and projector screen and an 8 KVA UPS valued at GHS 80,000.
justification: Project focuses on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Establishment of ICT lab with computers and educational equipment, no energy-related components mentioned

title: BOC contributes to $1.7 billion syndicated receivables-backed trade finance facility to COCOBOD for its 2014/2015 crop season financing needs (Linked to Project ID#92554)
description: On September 11, 2014, a consortium of 20 financial institutions — including the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Bank of China (BOC) — finalized a $1.5 billion receivables-backed trade finance facility (loan) agreement with Ghana Cocoa Board (COCOBOD), a state-owned enterprise and the world's second largest cocoa producer, for purchasing cocoa from farmers during the 2014/2015 crop season. The 20 participants in the loan syndicate included Barclays Bank PLC, Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, Deutsche Bank AG, KfW IPEX-Bank GmbH, Natixis, DZ BANK AG Deutsche Zentral-Genossenschafts bank Frankfurt am Main, Ghana International Bank plc, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Nedbank Limited, Rabobank International, Standard Bank Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, ABN AMRO Bank N.V., Bank of China, BHF Bank, Credit Agricole, Ecobank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, Intesa San Paolo, Société Générale, and Standard Chartered Bank.   The borrowing terms included a 1-year repayment period, an interest rate of LIBOR plus 60 basis points, a commitment fee of 0.35%, and an upfront fee of 0.575%. The Government of Ghana issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan. The loan was also secured by (i.e. collateralized against) receivables from future cocoa sales contracts.
staff_comments: 1. AidData has estimated the all-in interest rate by adding 0.60% to the average 6-month LIBOR rate in September 2014 (0.330%). 2. The individual contributions of the banks that participated in the lending syndicate are unknown. For the time being, AidData assumes equal contributions ($85 million) across all 20 members of the syndicate, which implies that the total financial commitment from Chinese state-owned banks was $170 million (ICBC's contribution is captured via Project ID#92554 while BOC's via project ID#92553. 3. Ghana’s cocoa production is regulated by the Ghana Cocoa Board (COCOBOD), an organization separate from the Ministry of Food and Agriculture that is wholly owned by the Government of Ghana. COCOBOD does not purchase any of the cocoa which is exported, but is responsible for assuring the quality of the product. To ensure the high quality of Ghana’s cocoa exports, the COCOBOD oversees horticulture practices and regulates the use of pesticides and fertilizer. In addition, COCOBOD sets the producer prices for cocoa farmers and, through a subsidiary, oversees the marketing of cocoa. The operations of the COCOBOD are funded through the receipt of a percentage of the revenue received from cocoa exports, but all profits after covering expenses are passed onto the Government of Ghana in the form of export taxes. 4. In August 2017, COCOBOD told the country’s parliament it was in financial distress due to obligations that included servicing China Eximbank loans for the Bui Dam Construction Project (captured via Project ID#183, ID#30801, ID#30709, and ID#30086). 5. The commitment fee is referred to in the source documentation as a ’35% on interest margin’. AidData has assumed that the 0.575% flat (upfront) fee is functionally equivalent to a management fee. 6. The security margin is the assignment of cocoa contracts for 110% of the facility amount. 7. This loan came with an additional $200 million available on demand for re-drawing from April 2015 to May 2015 for the light crop season.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
BOC contributes to $1.7 billion syndicated receivables-backed trade finance facility to COCOBOD for its 2014/2015 crop season financing needs (Linked to Project ID#92554)

# Description
On September 11, 2014, a consortium of 20 financial institutions — including the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Bank of China (BOC) — finalized a $1.5 billion receivables-backed trade finance facility (loan) agreement with Ghana Cocoa Board (COCOBOD), a state-owned enterprise and the world's second largest cocoa producer, for purchasing cocoa from farmers during the 2014/2015 crop season. The 20 participants in the loan syndicate included Barclays Bank PLC, Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, Deutsche Bank AG, KfW IPEX-Bank GmbH, Natixis, DZ BANK AG Deutsche Zentral-Genossenschafts bank Frankfurt am Main, Ghana International Bank plc, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Nedbank Limited, Rabobank International, Standard Bank Group, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, ABN AMRO Bank N.V., Bank of China, BHF Bank, Credit Agricole, Ecobank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, Intesa San Paolo, Société Générale, and Standard Chartered Bank.   The borrowing terms included a 1-year repayment period, an interest rate of LIBOR plus 60 basis points, a commitment fee of 0.35%, and an upfront fee of 0.575%. The Government of Ghana issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan. The loan was also secured by (i.e. collateralized against) receivables from future cocoa sales contracts.
justification: Project involves trade finance facility for cocoa purchasing, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Receivables-backed trade finance facility for cocoa crop season, financial services focus

title: Chinese Government provides $8,177 grant for Grenada Tri-centennial Park in 2014 (Linked to ProjectID#54768)
description: According to internal records that the Government of Grenada shared with AidData in June 2018, the Chinese Government provided a $8,177 grant to the Government of Grenada in 2014 to support the Tri-centennial Park Project. The Tri-centennial Park is a recreational park in St. George and a popular tourist attraction. The plans for the open-air park include building an amphitheatre to promote the arts and tourism as well as creating a 'Memorial Wall'.
staff_comments: 1. The main source (see Dropbox link) was provided to AidData by a Ministry of Finance official in Grenada. 2. This grant commitment should not confused with Project ID#54768, which captures a grant for the same park at a different time and for a different amount. 3. The project appears to be broken up into two phases: Phase I and Phase II. Details of the different phases could not be found, but in the Grenada Budget Speech for 2017 the spending details for Phase II were identified and in the 'explanation' column 'Kazakhstan' was listed, presumably as the provider of some of the funding. The Chinese government grants were not listed.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides $8,177 grant for Grenada Tri-centennial Park in 2014 (Linked to ProjectID#54768)

# Description
According to internal records that the Government of Grenada shared with AidData in June 2018, the Chinese Government provided a $8,177 grant to the Government of Grenada in 2014 to support the Tri-centennial Park Project. The Tri-centennial Park is a recreational park in St. George and a popular tourist attraction. The plans for the open-air park include building an amphitheatre to promote the arts and tourism as well as creating a 'Memorial Wall'.
justification: Project is focused on recreational and cultural development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Recreational park development, amphitheatre construction, tourism promotion
